sections.summary: This section announces a **declaration of immunity** from Allah and His Messenger toward polytheists who violated their agreements, granting a four-month period of grace. It ordains the combat of those who persist in **shirk** after the Sacred Months, while commanding protection for any who seek asylum to hear the Word of Allah.

The text critiques the **polytheists** for their disregard of kinship and treaties when they possess the upper hand. Believers are commanded to fight the leaders of **disbelief** to make them desist from their violations, thereby healing the hearts of the faithful and removing rage from their souls [138–139].

It is established that only those who believe in Allah and the Last Day are fit to maintain His **places of worship**. The verses emphasize that striving in the cause of Allah is superior to providing water for pilgrims, and that love for the Creator and His Messenger must exceed all **worldly ties** [139–140].

Allah reminds the believers of the **Battle of Hunayn**, where their large numbers did not avail them and they were forced into retreat. Victory was achieved only through divine **serenity (Sakinah)** and invisible reinforcements, followed by the acceptance of **repentance** for whom He wills.

Polytheists are barred from the **Sacred Mosque**, and the People of the Book are commanded to pay the **Jizya** tax as a sign of submission. The text refutes the claims of divine sonship for Ezra and the Messiah, condemning rabbis and priests who illicitly consume wealth and those who **hoard gold and silver** [140–141].

Allah decrees that the year consists of **twelve months**, four of which are **sacred**, prohibiting self-wronging therein. It condemns the practice of **Nasi’** (postponement of sacred months) as an increase in disbelief that misleads the ungrateful [141–142].

Believers are rebuked for clinging to the earth when called to mobilize for the cause of Allah. The narrative references Allah’s support for the Prophet in the **cave**, emphasizing that believers must strive with their **possessions and lives** regardless of the difficulty.

These verses expose **hypocrites** who sought exemption from military duty through lies and false oaths. Their contributions are rejected because of their **disbelief** and lazy approach to prayer, and their worldly wealth is framed as a means of divine **torment** [142–144].

A contrast is drawn between the hypocrites, who enjoin evil and withhold their hands, and the **believers**, who are allies to one another and enjoin virtue. While the former face eternal **curse** and Fire, the latter are promised **Gardens of Eden** and the supreme achievement of Allah’s approval [144–146].

The Prophet is commanded to be stern with disbelievers and hypocrites whose hearts are hardened despite the **grace** Allah bestowed upon them. It is noted that even if the Messenger seeks **forgiveness** for them seventy times, Allah will not forgive those who renounced faith.

Those who stayed behind the Messenger are rebuked for preferring comfort over the heat of the **struggle**. The Prophet is forbidden from performing **funeral prayers** over them, while the successful believers are praised for their commitment of wealth and persons [146–147].

The text distinguishes between the Desert-Arabs who are steeped in **hypocrisy** and those who view their contributions as a means of **nearness** to Allah. It clarifies that no blame attaches to the weak or sick who are sincere to Allah and His Messenger [147–148].

Divine pleasure is announced for the **Migrants (Muhajireen)** and **Supporters (Ansar)**. For those who mixed good and bad deeds, **repentance** is accepted through the purification of their wealth, while others remain held in suspense awaiting Allah’s decree [148–149].

The narrative condemns the building of **Masjid ad-Dirar** (the Mosque of Harm) as a center for disbelief and division. Believers are instructed to pray only in structures founded upon **piety** from the first day [149–150].

Allah declares He has purchased the souls and properties of believers in exchange for **Paradise**. It prohibits seeking forgiveness for **polytheists** and recounts the redemption of those who hesitated during the hour of difficulty [150–151].

Believers are commanded to be with the **sincere** and told that every hardship endured in Allah's cause is recorded. The text establishes that a group must remain behind to gain **understanding of religion** to teach others, while exposing how the Quran increases the **faith** of believers but adds disgrace to the diseased hearts [151–152].

The surah concludes by describing the Messenger as deeply concerned for the welfare of the people and **compassionate** toward believers. If they turn away, he is instructed to declare his absolute **trust in Allah**, the Lord of the Sublime Throne.
